title: Corrections: June 21, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, June 21, 2023.
content: An article on Sunday about Ron DeSantis’s age compared with that of other presidential candidates misstated the number of voters between the ages of 35 and 49 who had a favorable view of Mr. DeSantis, according to a Quinnipiac University poll. It was about two in five, not about one in four.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Biggest Threat to Submersible’s Passengers May Now Be Dwindling Oxygen
description: There may be less than a day’s worth of breathable air left in the Titan, limiting the window for possible rescue of the five people on board.
content: As search and rescue teams scour the North Atlantic for the missing submersible Titan, one overriding question may dictate the fate of the five passengers: How much oxygen is left?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Kansas Man Accused of Threatening to Attack Nashville Pride Event
description: Joshua Hensley, 25, wrote on Facebook that he planned to make pressure-cooker bombs and to “commit a mass shooting” at Nashville Pride this weekend, prosecutors said.
content: A Kansas man has been indicted on charges of threatening to commit violent attacks at a Pride event in Nashville this month, federal prosecutors said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Odesa Was Ready to Reclaim Its Beaches. Then a Dam Broke.
description: Wartime fears closed the Ukrainian city’s famed beaches last year, but crowds were starting to return — until the destruction of a faraway dam dumped debris and dangers into the Black Sea.
content: Last summer, the beaches that ring the port city of Odesa in southern Ukraine were crowded with volunteers packing sandbags under bluffs where troops were positioned in machine gun nests as the threat of a Russian amphibious assault still loomed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: U.K. Inflation Remains Stuck at 8.7%
description: The rate, which had been expected to edge lower in May, shows that Britain’s cost-of-living crisis persists, and is likely to prompt the Bank of England to raise interest rates again.
content: Britain’s inflation rate held steady in May, frustrating expectations that price increases would slow down, according to data released Wednesday, the day before the country’s central bank is widely expected to raise interest rates again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nanna Bonde Thylstrup
title: The World’s Digital Memory Is at Risk
description: Digital archives are humanity’s collective memory. Who should control them, and how, is a major problem for digital societies.
content: A constant hum drones out of a former church in San Francisco. It is the sound, from hundreds of fans cooling hundreds of computer servers, of the digital past being kept alive. This is the Internet Archive, the largest collection of archived web pages in the world and a constant reminder of the fragility of our digital past. It is also, thanks to a March ruling in a federal court, which found that the archive’s lending practices violate publishers’ rights, just one battlefield in a growing struggle that will define how humanity’s collective digital memory is owned, shared and preserved — or lost forever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘No Hard Feelings’ Review: How Lucky Can a Nerdy Kid Get?
description: That time when Mom and Dad hired Jennifer Lawrence to introduce you to the pleasures of the opposite sex before you started college.
content: The premise that motors “No Hard Feelings,” a new comedy directed by Gene Stupnitsky, is, if not outright indecent, at least a little crass. Via online advertisement, Laird and Allison, megawealthy Montauk residents, are seeking an attractive woman in her early 20s to deflower their socially awkward Princeton-bound son, Percy. In return for this service they’ll bestow a not-quite brand-new car on the kinda-sorta prostitute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Property Taxes to Be Cut in Half for Most Older N.J. Homeowners
description: The budget deal is expected to result in taxpayer savings of as much as $6,500 a year, representing one of the largest tax cuts in New Jersey history.
content: New Jersey has some of the highest property taxes in the country, a fact often cited by older residents who choose to sell their homes to either downsize or move out of state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israeli Settlers Attack Palestinian Towns After Shooting
description: A day after Palestinian gunmen killed four people, Israelis set fires in Palestinian areas and their government hastened plans to expand settlements in the occupied West Bank.
content: Israeli extremists caused widespread damage in a wave of attacks on Palestinian towns that lasted from Tuesday night until Wednesday night in revenge for the killing of four Israelis by Palestinian gunmen outside a nearby settlement in the territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: The Government Must Say What It Knows About Covid’s Origins
description: Transparency is how to fight misinformation.
content: Three researchers at a laboratory in Wuhan, China, who had fallen ill in November 2019 had been experimenting with SARS-like coronaviruses under inadequate biosafety conditions, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday, citing current and former U.S. officials.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Hunter Biden’s Plea Deal and Donald Trump’s Defense
description: Readers discuss the cases of the former president and the current president’s son. Also: New York Harbor; hospice care; prison dancers; Pride flags.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Olivia Bensimon
title: Rents for 2 Million New Yorkers to Rise Again This Year
description: Rent-stabilized apartments have enabled many people to stay in a city that grows ever more expensive. But for the second year in a row, rents will rise.
content: For the second consecutive year, a New York City panel that regulates the rents for roughly one million rent-stabilized apartments approved Wednesday some of the highest increases in a decade, as inflation and rising expenses for property owners continue to aggravate the city’s affordability problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Firestone
title: The High Price of Petulance in the Senate
description: What’s new about the latest version of these Senate holds is the breadth and long-term nature of their effects.
content: Instead of showing up for work last Tuesday, Senator Tommy Tuberville, Republican of Alabama, went to Donald Trump’s golf club in Bedminster, N.J., to hear the former president rail against his latest criminal indictment. Mr. Tuberville’s absence from the Capitol gave the Senate an opportunity to end his one-man blockade of all military promotions, a campaign he has been waging for four months to protest the Pentagon’s policy paying for service members to travel for an abortion if they live in a state where it is illegal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval and Judson Jones
title: Extreme Heat and More Storms Threaten an Already Battered Oklahoma
description: Thousands of people were without power in the state, and days of sweltering temperatures are expected to put further strain on resources there and in Texas.
content: Battered by severe storms that killed at least two people and left thousands without electricity, Oklahoma faced relentless heat and more severe storms on Wednesday as crews worked furiously to restore power in the hard-hit northeast part of the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $450,000 Homes in Oklahoma, Missouri and Rhode Island
description: A Craftsman bungalow in Oklahoma City, a Tudor Revival house in St. Louis and a Colonial Revival cottage in Cranston.
content: This house is in Mesta Park, a neighborhood listed on the National Register of Historic Places because of its Craftsman homes dating to the early 20th century. It is within walking distance of a park and a stretch of NW 23rd Street with several Vietnamese restaurants; doughnut, ice cream and coffee shops; and Tower Theatre, a 1937 theater that is now a venue for live entertainment and film screenings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Burdick and Elaine Chen
title: Our Plan to Attract a Flock of Birders
description: In its first-ever citizen science project, The Times is encouraging readers to go birding and help researchers gather data on the avian world.
content: We would not count ourselves as birders. Elaine, who visited the Everglades occasionally when she lived in Miami, knows a purple gallinule when she sees one. Alan can tell a red-tailed hawk from a sharp-shinned one, having been dragged as a child every spring to the southern shore of Lake Ontario to watch raptors migrate north. But such traits alone do not a birder make.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Quick and Easy Skillet Chocolate Chip Cookie
description: Treat yourself, too, to 7Up sheet cake and sweet cream cold foam to marble into your iced coffee.
content: Surely no one with a sweet tooth and a pulse can resist a skillet-size giant chocolate chip cookie (above). I certainly can’t. It’s so much easier and quicker than the usual cookies you have to scoop and bake in batches, since here you just press the dough directly into the pan. The payoff is eating the slices fresh from the oven, when the slightly too hot wedges sting your fingertips and the chips are just gooey enough. This is the chewy, chocolaty, brown sugar-filled treat that you deserve right now, and it’s an utter snap to make.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: Searchers Cannot Tell Yet if Banging Sounds Are Clues to Missing Vessel
description: The underwater sounds, heard on Tuesday and again on Wednesday, come at half-hour intervals, suggesting they might be made by people on the missing submersible.
content: Underwater banging sounds, detected on Tuesday and again on Wednesday, might be an intriguing clue to the disappearance of a submersible on Sunday near the wreck of the Titanic — or they might just be unrelated noise. Searchers do not yet know which.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Mujib Mashal
title: In Hosting Modi, Biden Pushes Democracy Concerns to the Background
description: The president who declared “the battle between democracy and autocracy” to be the defining struggle of his time has concluded that he needs to accept some imperfect but important friends.
content: President Biden has declared “the battle between democracy and autocracy” to be the defining struggle of his time. But when he rolls out the red carpet on the South Lawn of the White House for Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India on Thursday morning, Mr. Biden will effectively call a temporary truce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Special Counsel Who Hunted for a Deep-State Conspiracy Presents Muted Findings
description: John H. Durham, the Trump-era special counsel, criticized the F.B.I. during a six-hour hearing before the House Judiciary Committee.
content: John H. Durham, the Trump-era special counsel who for four years pursued a politically fraught investigation into the Russia inquiry, told lawmakers on Wednesday that F.B.I. officials had exhibited confirmation bias — even as he defended his work against Democratic accusations that he became a partisan tool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Haim Roet, Who Kept Holocaust Victims’ Names Alive, Dies at 90
description: Since he first read the names of people murdered by the Nazis at a protest in 1989, the practice has become a part of memorial ceremonies around the world.
content: Rosina Roet. Adelheid Roet. Abraham Roet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Italian Men’s Wear Does a Power Edit
description: Lauren showed psychedelic tuxedos, Armani and Zegna stripped things down and Chris Pine made the rounds during a potent fashion season in Florence and Milan.
content: Concision — that was the word to come to mind after eight surprising days in this men’s wear capital, and in Florence. Did some unseen force take a blue pencil to all the slack narratives, rehashed inspirations, derivative references that prevailed in recent seasons? Suddenly everything seemed crisp and focused, like early Hemingway after he’d learned how to do Gertrude Stein.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and James C. McKinley Jr
title: Undersea Noises Become Focus of Submersible Rescue Effort
description: The unexplained sounds offered a slender line of hope to rescuers who have been scouring a patch of the North Atlantic twice the size of Connecticut.
content: Unexplained noises detected beneath the waves of the North Atlantic became the focus on Wednesday of an urgent search for five people inside a submersible that disappeared three days earlier during a dive to the wreckage of the R.M.S. Titanic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: F.T.C. Sues Amazon for Tricking Users Into Subscribing to Prime
description: The lawsuit is the first time that the Federal Trade Commission under its chair, Lina Khan, has taken Amazon to court.
content: The Federal Trade Commission sued Amazon on Wednesday, accusing it of illegally inducing consumers to sign up for its Prime service and then hindering them from canceling the subscription, in the most aggressive action against the company to date by the agency’s chair, Lina Khan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Houman Barekat
title: ‘Dear England’ Review: When Soccer Success Becomes a Moral Victory
description: A new James Graham play about the soccer coach Gareth Southgate is a lively romp, but its core message about embracing male vulnerability feels soppy.
content: What makes a good leader? When the unassuming and softly spoken Gareth Southgate was appointed head coach of the England men’s soccer team in 2016, many fans and commentators felt he lacked the kahunas for the role, that he was simply too nice. But in the past seven years he has overseen a remarkable transformation in the England team’s fortunes, making it stronger and more exciting to watch than at any time in recent history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Daniel Ellsberg, Pentagon Papers Source, Had Uneasy Relationship With The Times
description: Mr. Ellsberg took issue with how the newspaper portrayed his role, and how he was treated by the project’s primary reporter.
content: The relationship between The New York Times and its most famous source, Daniel Ellsberg, reads like a thriller, replete with clandestine meetings, top secret documents and a war raging in the background.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Harmon
title: How It Feels to Have Your Life Changed By Affirmative Action
description: Black and Hispanic college graduates, whose lives were directly shaped by race-conscious college admissions, have complicated thoughts about the expected Supreme Court decision.
content: As a top student at his Philadelphia high school in 1968, Granderson Hale knew he stood a decent chance of admission at one of the historically Black colleges that typically sent recruiters to the school, where nearly all of the 2,700 students were Black.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Harsh New Fentanyl Laws Ignite Debate Over How to Combat Overdose Crisis
description: Critics say a fierce law-and-order approach could undermine public health goals and advances in addiction treatment.
content: Three teenage girls were found slumped in a car in the parking lot of a rural Tennessee high school last month, hours before graduation ceremonies. Two were dead from fentanyl overdoses. The third, a 17-year-old, was rushed to the hospital in critical condition. Two days later, she was charged with the girls’ murders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Modi’s Pomp-Filled State Visit
description: Also, more vessels search for the missing sub. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: At the White House tonight, President Biden will host Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India for a private dinner that will kick off a pomp-filled state visit, matched only by visits from America’s closest allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: ‘I Don’t Know How You Can Block the Plate From Behind the Plate’
description: Catcher Jonah Heim of the Rangers was baffled by a game-deciding call. His manager called it “absolutely one of the worst calls I’ve ever seen.”
content: For years, fans and players alike have complained that no one is sure what constitutes a catch in the N.F.L. It appears that no one knows what blocking the plate means in Major League Baseball either.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Miller
title: The Bargain You Make Living in America May No Longer Hold
description: Less for more. That’s the fundamental bargain, as it’s been construed since Roe v. Wade and the Reagan revolution.
content: Here’s the American bargain: less for more. Less from the government, in exchange for more of yourself. More privacy, more speech, more ability to move wherever you might want to go and to associate with whomever you like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: Gooped at a Gwyneth Paltrow Drag Show
description: Partygoers donned glitter and gowns in homage to the actress and jade egg enthusiast at a party in Brooklyn.
content: Gwyneth Paltrow has been popping up in unexpected places this year. She was in court in March, dressed impeccably, and won $1 after being found not at fault for a ski crash. She was on a cruise ship. And on Friday evening at 3 Dollar Bill, a queer club in the East Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn, she was onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: The doomed ocean liner Titanic continues to intrigue the public after more than a century.
description: The mystique has endured long after the vessel, for decades the holy grail of undiscovered shipwrecks, was found on the sea floor in 1985.
content: The five people aboard the missing deep-sea submersible Titan are not the first to risk their lives for a chance to glimpse one of history’s most famous shipwrecks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Going Bankrupt in the Name of Efficiency
description: Two new books offer harsh assessments of private equity firms that specializes in buying up companies only to saddle them with debt and squeeze them for profits.
content: In “These Are the Plunderers: How Private Equity Runs — and Wrecks — America,” a new book by Gretchen Morgenson and Joshua Rosner, the arguments are about as subtle as a wrecking ball. It’s a measure of just how inflamed the rhetoric can be that when I arrived at the chapter called “‘Like When Hitler Invaded Poland in 1939,’” I assumed the authors were the ones drawing the analogy. In addition to the “plunderers” of the title, their book is full of “money-spinners,” “buyout boys,” “pirates,” “pillagers” and “marauders”; a resident at a private equity-owned nursing home was forced to undergo, in the authors’ ghastly description, “a Bataan-like death march of therapy sessions.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: SoftBank’s Masayoshi Son Shifts to ‘Offense’ in A.I. Race
description: After lying low last year and “crying for days,” the founder and chief executive of the tech conglomerate said he was excited again about the future.
content: For months, Masayoshi Son, SoftBank’s voluble founder and chief executive, kept quiet as his tech conglomerate struggled with huge investment losses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Zia ur-Rehman
title: ‘Like Doomsday’: How Hope of a Better Life Ended on a Boat in the Mediterranean
description: About two dozen of those on the fishing vessel that capsized off Greece came from Bandli, a community in northeastern Pakistan with a long history of young men chasing a brighter future abroad.
content: There was no changing their minds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: So Your Plant Is Sick? Here’s How to Get a Diagnosis.
description: Welcome to the ‘disease garden’: It’s not pretty, but it’s full of answers.
content: In a garden she developed by the corner of a building on Purdue University’s campus, in West Lafayette, Ind., Janna L. Beckerman invites trouble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Delaware’s Only House Member Enters Senate Race, Becoming Instant Favorite
description: Lisa Blunt Rochester, the handpicked successor to retiring Senator Thomas R. Carper, would be the third Black woman in history to win a Senate seat.
content: Representative Lisa Blunt Rochester, a Democrat, announced her campaign on Wednesday for the Delaware Senate seat being vacated by Senator Thomas R. Carper, beginning as the favorite in a race that could make her the third Black woman in U.S. history to win election to the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Alito’s Reply in a Rival Publication Surprises ProPublica
description: The Wall Street Journal made the unusual decision to let Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. pre-empt ProPublica’s article about him in its opinion pages.
content: The Wall Street Journal faced criticism on Wednesday after its highly unusual decision to let Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. pre-empt another media organization’s article about him by publishing his response in its opinion pages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Golembiewski
title: The Secret in the Spots on Monarch Butterflies’ Wings
description: The wings of monarchs that survive a 2,000-mile-long migration tend to be spottier, suggesting that feature may aid the insects’ ability to fly.
content: Every fall, monarch butterflies embark on one of nature’s greatest journeys. These insects flap more than 2,000 miles from their summer homes in Canada down to the mountains of central Mexico. Only about 30 percent survive the trip. Researchers have found a shared trait in the butterflies that make it: The edges of their wings tend to be slightly spottier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Mailbag: Does Trump Represent Half the Country?
description: Settling a marital dispute, and a question that gets at a tension within today’s conservatism — in this month’s reader mailbag.
content: Whenever possible, it’s important for both partners to feel good with the settlement of a marital dispute. So let me suggest that the answer depends on your preferred definition of a “Trump supporter.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Elyssa Dudley, Hans Buetow, Jen Poyant, Sara Sarasohn, Sophia Lanman, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Pat McCusker
title: What I Got Wrong About My Parents’ Marriage
description: The unconventional child of a conventional Indian family realizes she overlooked the affection in her parents’ marriage.
content: As one of the only Indian girls in her tiny Canadian mountain town, Natasha Singh stood out — and she was unafraid of being different. At 13, she shaved her head. By 17, she had run away for good. A few years later, she came out to her mother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: To Improve Public Housing, New York City Moves to Tear It Down
description: After surveying residents at two developments in Manhattan, the agency is moving forward with a $1.5 billion plan to demolish and replace the buildings.
content: Tearing down public housing has become something of a national trend, except in New York, where the New York City Housing Authority has held onto its stock of aging buildings even as repair bills and tenant complaints mount.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Oscars’ Best Picture Hopefuls Must Spend More Time in Theaters
description: To be eligible for the academy’s top prize, films will need to have an initial theatrical run of a week in one of six U.S. cities, and then expand to other cities across the country.
content: In a move designed to signal Hollywood’s commitment to the moviegoing experience, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Wednesday that it would require an expanded theatrical release for films seeking to be eligible for a best picture nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin and Brooks Barnes
title: Producer Ryan Murphy Is Expected to Move to Disney
description: Mr. Murphy, the force behind hits like “American Horror Story” and “The Watcher,” is coming to the end of his $300 million Netflix deal.
content: Ryan Murphy, the television megaproducer behind hits like “American Horror Story” and “Monster: The Jeffrey Dahmer Story,” is poised to move his operation to the Walt Disney Company, five years after he stunned Hollywood by decamping to Netflix for a $300 million deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Chair Sees ‘Long Way to Go’ on Inflation Fight
description: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, told House lawmakers that most central bank officials expect rates to rise further.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, told House lawmakers that the United States remains a “long way” away from low and stable inflation even 15 months into the central bank’s campaign to cool the economy and wrestle down rapid price increases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Ukraine’s soccer fans team up to support the war effort.
description: At the Corner Pub in Kyiv, supporters are cheering on their team, but they have also become fund-raisers, military boosters and logistics experts providing equipment to the front lines.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — More than 100 people were rooting for Ukraine’s national soccer team in the front of the Corner Pub, but a look at the back rooms of the bar made it clear that its customers were more than just sports fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: perfunctorily
description: This word has appeared in seven articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word perfunctorily has appeared in seven articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 19 in “How a Psychologist Confronted Her Own Bipolar Disorder” by Kay Redfield Jamison:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Is the Inflation Battle Won? Not Yet.
description: Inflation has come down from its 2022 heights, but economists are worried about its stubbornness.
content: Inflation is beginning to abate meaningfully for American consumers. Gas is cheaper, eggs cost roughly half as much as they did in January and prices are no longer climbing as rapidly across a wide array of products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Maxine Waters Proposes Billions to Expand Low-Income Housing
description: Nearly one in three Americans living on the street and in shelters are in the representative’s home state of California.
content: In a sweeping effort to expand affordable housing and combat homelessness, Representative Maxine Waters of California introduced a package of three bills on Wednesday aimed at narrowing the country’s racial wealth gap.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Pharrell Williams at Louis Vuitton and Gunna’s New LP
description: What’s the role of global celebrity in high fashion? Why hasn’t hip-hop penetrated the charts this year? And what’s the snack of the week?
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: Why Is Narendra Modi So Popular? Tune In to Find Out.
description: The Indian leader, who visits Washington this week, has softened his image at home with an old-fashioned radio show, which feeds a vast social media apparatus.
content: Once a month, India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, walks into a studio set up at his government bungalow and takes his seat behind a microphone. The air-conditioning is switched off to quiet its hum. Thick curtains maintain the room’s silence even from Mr. Modi’s favorite peacocks in the garden outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Why California Transit Agencies Are Rebounding at Such Different Rates
description: Who rides public transportation has shifted since the onset of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: In California, already famous for its love of automobiles, our dependence on cars only deepened during the coronavirus pandemic, as millions of people stopped commuting by train or bus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Waiting for the Justices
description: We’re covering the coming affirmative action ruling, the search for a submersible and Hunter Biden.
content: Sometime in the next 10 days, the Supreme Court is expected to tightly restrict or ban race-based affirmative action in college admissions. The ruling could come as soon as tomorrow or as late as Friday, June 30, before the justices leave for their summer break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller, Alicia Parlapiano and Madeleine Ngo
title: Child Care Disruptions Expected as Record Funding Nears an End
description: Three million children could be affected as the largest investment in child care in U.S. history expires in September.
content: For two years, the United States has been effectively running an experiment in federally funding child care providers. The $24 billion disbursed in pandemic relief has been the largest investment in child care in U.S. history. Child care providers have used the money to raise teachers’ pay, buy supplies and pay mortgages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: What the New, Low Test Scores for 13-Year-Olds Say About U.S. Education Now
description: The results are the federal government’s last major data release on the academic effects of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: The math and reading performance of 13-year-olds in the United States has hit the lowest level in decades, according to test scores released today from the National Assessment of Educational Progress, the gold-standard federal exam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Garland’s Distance From Hunter Biden Inquiry Fails to Quell Critics
description: The attorney general has confronted an unrelenting succession of politically sensitive investigations, underlining the intensely polarized environment he is operating in.
content: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland was 4,000 miles away from Delaware on Tuesday when federal prosecutors announced a deal for Hunter Biden on tax and gun charges that would most likely ensure he does not serve a prison sentence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: Arrest of Mexican Army General Ordered in Case of Missing Students
description: The 43 students are believed to have been murdered in 2014, an atrocity that galvanized the country. The arrest warrant names a general and 15 other soldiers.
content: Mexican prosecutors have obtained a warrant for the arrests of an Army general and 15 other soldiers in connection with the disappearance of 43 students in 2014, a crime considered one of the worst atrocities in the country’s recent history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: A Superyacht Gave a Lifeline to 100 Migrants Thrown Into the Sea
description: A $175 million vessel responded to a distress call and helped rescue survivors in one of the Mediterranean’s worst wrecks in decades, reflecting the new inequality of the seas.
content: The superyacht Mayan Queen IV was sailing smoothly in clear weather through the dark and calm Mediterranean in the early hours of June 14 when it received a call about a migrant ship in distress four nautical miles away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Business Leaders Join Biden in Welcoming Modi to the U.S.
description: India’s fast-growing economy is drawing American corporate giants, even as the country faces scrutiny over ties to Russia and limits on political freedoms.
content: The White House is rolling out the red carpet for Narendra Modi, India’s prime minister, with a state dinner on Thursday. High on the agenda: Talks to strengthen economic and security ties as the Biden administration cultivates partners to counter China. Business is watching closely, too, as it pours money into one of the world’s fastest-growing big economies despite the challenges of operating there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: The Invasive Giant African Land Snail Has Been Spotted in Florida
description: The appearance of the snails caused the state’s agriculture department to place parts of the second-largest county in Florida in quarantine, making it illegal to move the animals.
content: An invasive species of large snail that can grow as large as a human fist and carries a parasite that can cause meningitis has been spotted in Florida’s second-most-populous county, prompting officials to set up a quarantine zone to try to contain it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: People on Drugs Like Ozempic Say Their ‘Food Noise’ Has Disappeared
description: For some, it’s a startling side effect.
content: Until she started taking the weight loss drug Wegovy, Staci Klemmer’s days revolved around food. When she woke up, she plotted out what she would eat; as soon as she had lunch, she thought about dinner. After leaving work as a high school teacher in Bucks County, Pa., she would often drive to Taco Bell or McDonald’s to quell what she called a “24/7 chatter” in the back of her mind. Even when she was full, she wanted to eat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Prosecutors Disclose Discovery of Secret Guantánamo Prison Videos
description: A war court prosecutor said the videos, which could cause more delays in the destroyer Cole bombing case, were so sensitive that the public couldn’t see them and the judge couldn’t have a copy.
content: Prosecutors have discovered secret videos of guards forcibly removing the accused mastermind of the bombing of the Navy destroyer Cole from his cell at Guantánamo Bay around the time federal agents claim he voluntarily confessed to his role in the Qaeda plot, the lead prosecutor told the trial judge on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Emmys May Be Pushed Back Because of Writers’ Strike
description: Organizers of the September event are said to be discussing a postponement, possibly for months, if the strike lasts deep into the summer.
content: More fallout from the Hollywood writers’ strike could be on the horizon: a postponed Emmy Awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: These Fish Tacos Couldn’t Be More Brilliant
description: Golden pineapple and a deep-red marinade make this dish pop with color and flavor.
content: When Luis Herrera is cooking, Korean gochugaru, Thai curry paste and Venezuelan ají dulce make their way into his pots and pans. They appear as often as guajillo and ancho chiles and fresh masa milled down the block from his Mexican restaurant, Ensenada, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Inspired by the compatibility of various cuisines, the Venezuelan chef finds moments of ingenuity every day, pulling especially from Latin American influences. “I think that’s when greatness happens,” he says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: 2 Women and 2 Ways of Wielding Power in New York
description: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is staying out of local politics right now, while Ingrid Lewis-Martin is a major figure behind the scenes.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at two powerful figures in New York City politics — one who is well-known and one who isn’t. We’ll also get details on a fire that renewed concerns about the dangers of batteries for e-bikes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Catrin Einhorn
title: Biden Administration Moves to Restore Endangered Species Protections
description: New rules would void Trump-era changes that made it easier to remove animals and plants from the endangered list.
content: The Biden administration moved on Wednesday to make it easier to protect wildlife from climate disruptions and other threats, restoring protections to the Endangered Species Act that President Donald J. Trump had removed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: Everyone Likes Reading. Why Are We So Afraid of It?
description: Book bans, chatbots, pedagogical warfare: What it means to read has become a minefield.
content: Everyone loves reading. In principle, anyway. Nobody is against it, right? Surely, in the midst of our many quarrels, we can agree that people should learn to read, should learn to enjoy it and should do a lot of it. But bubbling underneath this bland, upbeat consensus is a simmer of individual anxiety and collective panic. We are in the throes of a reading crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Dozens of Migrants Bound for Canary Islands Feared Dead as Boat Sinks
description: Twenty-four people were rescued and two confirmed dead, but 35 others were missing after an inflatable vessel heading to the Spanish archipelago sank, an aid group said.
content: At least two migrants died and 35 more were feared dead after an inflatable boat en route to the Canary Islands, a Spanish archipelago off northwestern Africa, sank on Wednesday, according to the Spanish authorities and an aid group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justice Alito Defends Private Jet Travel to Luxury Fishing Trip
description: In an opinion essay in The Wall Street Journal, the justice disputed a ProPublica report, saying he was not required to disclose the trip or recuse himself from his benefactor’s cases.
content: Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. took the unusual step late Tuesday of responding to questions about his travel with a billionaire who frequently has cases before the Supreme Court hours before an article detailing their ties had even been published.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Good Vibrations’ Review: The Saving Power of Punk
description: In a big-hearted musical about a 1970s Belfast record store owner and the punk movement he nurtured, music is the real hero.
content: On a nighttime street in 1970s Belfast, Northern Ireland, a D.J. named Terri Hooley runs into a pair of local toughs — young men who’ve found their purpose in the gunfire and explosions of a sectarian conflict pitting Protestants against Catholics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: This Salon Works to Understand Black Women’s Hair
description: Each week, the global conglomerate Unilever brings people into a salon to test new products. It’s hoping to get a bigger piece of the long undervalued but growing Black beauty market.
content: On a recent spring afternoon, Marcella Roberts and Brooke Council sat in a salon chatting about how much they liked their hair. The two women, who are Black, were discussing a new cream they had been using to style and moisturize their curly hairstyles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost
title: Glastonbury, Conn.: A Friendly Community With Grand Historic Homes
description: The Hartford suburb draws residents with its bustling downtown, plentiful activities and long history (including a ferry established in 1655).
content: Diana Gallagher and her husband, Tony Patelunas, ended up in the Hartford suburb of Glastonbury, Conn., almost by chance. In 2021, they were living in Windham and looking for homes in the general vicinity, close to the University of Connecticut, when a colonial-style house in Glastonbury caught their eye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Search for a missing submersible craft.
content: An international team of rescuers was racing against time to search thousands of square miles of the North Atlantic for a deep-diving submersible with five people on board and a dwindling supply of oxygen. A staggering list of logistical challenges has complicated the operation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: At U.N., Narendra Modi Celebrates Yoga, and Joins In on a Pose
description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi has cracked down on dissent in India. In New York on Wednesday, he stressed inclusivity.
content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, on a three-day visit to the United States, kicked off a group yoga session for international diplomats on the lawn of the United Nations in Manhattan on Wednesday morning, stressing the nondenominational aspect of the practice that has roots in Hindu spirituality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Explosion Rocks Central Paris, Injuring at Least 37 People
description: The blast, in the Fifth Arrondissement of the French capital, started a blaze that firefighters quickly brought under control. The origin of the explosion, which critically injured four people, was unclear.
content: An explosion tore through an apartment building in central Paris on Wednesday, partly collapsing the structure and injuring at least 37 people, four of them critically, according to the French authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Allies Pledge Billions for Ukraine’s Recovery as Zelensky Stresses Urgency
description: The price tag for reconstruction has soared, driving debate among U.S. and European officials, legal experts and others about using frozen Russian assets to pay for it.
content: Western countries pledged tens of billions of dollars to rebuild war-torn Ukraine on Wednesday, as leaders gathered at a two-day conference convened by the British government in the shadow of Ukraine’s counteroffensive against Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Battling Russia, Ukrainian Leaders Also Fight High Expectations
description: Seeking to bolster morale and Western support, President Volodymyr Zelensky and his aides say that the slow progress of Ukraine’s counteroffensive is to be expected.
content: As much of the world pays close attention to the slow progress of Ukraine’s counteroffensive, its leaders are trying to tamp down expectations, saying that the fight to expel the Russian invaders was inevitably going to be a hard, bloody slog, not a lightning advance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Vineyard
title: ‘And Just Like That …’ Is Back. Here’s What to Remember.
description: The new season, premiering Thursday on Max, promises the return of beloved figures from the franchise’s past. Here’s a quick primer on who’s who and how they all fit together.
content: “Sex and the City” premiered just over 25 years ago, on June 6, 1998, and since then much has been lost in a franchise that now includes six seasons of the original HBO show, two films and the Max follow-up series, “And Just Like That …”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Cyranoski
title: How a Scientific Fraud Reinvented Himself
description: The rehabilitation of Hwang Woo-suk speaks volumes.
content: Science is known for rigorous self-policing by the research community, yet it can feel like scientific fraud is rampant. Why do fraudsters think they can get away with it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Senate Democrats Seek to Highlight G.O.P. Opposition to Abortion Rights
description: Democrats brought to the floor a set of bills intended to protect women’s health and reproductive freedom, knowing they would be blocked by Republicans.
content: Senate Democrats on Wednesday forced consideration of measures intended to protect women’s health and reproductive freedom, using the upcoming anniversary of the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade to remind voters of Republican opposition to measures with broad voter approval.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman and Traci Angel
title: Former F.B.I. Analyst Goes to Prison for Taking Classified Documents
description: Like former President Trump, the former analyst was accused of violating the Espionage Act, taking home hundreds of classified documents and being unhelpful.
content: A former F.B.I. intelligence analyst from Kansas received nearly four years in prison on Wednesday in a case that bears parallels to that of former President Donald J. Trump, including the same charge of willful retention of national security secrets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Andrew Tate’s Indictment in Romania: Here’s What to Know
description: The online influencer and his brother, Tristan Tate, appeared in court for the first time since their indictment on charges including human trafficking.
content: Andrew Tate, a wealth-flaunting online influencer known for his male chauvinism and misogynistic views, has been indicted in Romania for human trafficking and forming an organized criminal group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman, Charlie Savage and Jonathan Weisman
title: Few of Trump’s G.O.P. Rivals Defend Justice Dept. Independence
description: The evolution of the Republican Party under the influence of former President Donald J. Trump calls into question a post-Watergate norm.
content: Donald J. Trump has promised that if he wins back the presidency he will appoint a special prosecutor to “go after” President Biden and his family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aruna D'Souza
title: Hidden in a Mini-Mall in Flushing, a Home for Art
description: In a Queens neighborhood with a diverse community of East Asian immigrants, an unlikely exhibition in an unexpected place offers a sense of belonging.
content: The flier announcing a new exhibition in Queens, “Home-O-Stasis,” doesn’t give an address. Instead, it has instructions: When you reach the Queens Public Library in Flushing, “go up to Kissena Boulevard till you see the Q17/Q27 stop. Go past the garage gate, enter the mini-mall on the right where scooters and bikes are parked outside.” (How you get to the library is up to you and Google maps.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Wife Lives in a Nursing Home. Can I Take a Lover?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what is permissible in a marriage.
content: My wife and I have been married for 50 years; she has been “at death’s door” for the last 30 of them and institutionalized for the past seven years because of her poor health. She’s 68, and I’m 71. There has been no love or intimacy for the past 10 years. We can’t afford to divorce. I am raising three grandkids that we adopted. The two older kids are intellectually disabled because of fetal alcohol syndrome and will never live independently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: U.S. Approves the Sale of Lab-Grown Chicken
description: The Agriculture Department granted approval to cultivated meat producers for the first time in the United States, representing a watershed moment for the alternative protein industry.
content: The Agriculture Department approved the production and sale of laboratory-grown meat for the first time on Wednesday, clearing the way for two California companies to sell chicken produced from animal cells.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: House Censures Adam Schiff Over His Role Investigating Trump
description: The move by the G.O.P.-led House was the first in what could be a series of votes seeking to punish those whom Republicans have deemed enemies of the party.
content: The G.O.P.-led House formally censured Representative Adam B. Schiff, Democrat of California, on Wednesday over his role investigating former President Donald J. Trump, the first in what could be a series of votes seeking to punish those whom Republicans have deemed the party’s enemies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Jean-Baptiste
title: The Artist Making Glassware With Solange Knowles and Saint Heron
description: Jason McDonald became a glassblower knowing that throughout history, there’s little to no record of Black glassblowers. He’d like to change that.
content: Jason McDonald discovered glassblowing more than two decades ago at an after school program in his hometown, Tacoma, Wash. He was 14 at the time, and it was nothing like anything he had ever seen before, he said: immediate, dangerous and sobering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: R.I.P., the Sun Triangle
description: A Manhattan installation that pointed to the wonders of astronomy is gone but not forgotten.
content: When you throw a yellow beach ball upward, it slows down, comes to a stop for a moment and then comes back down, gaining speed as it falls. Now imagine that beach ball is the sun, getting higher in the sky each noon from December until June until one day it stops getting higher. That day is the summer solstice — from the Latin “solstitium,” or “point at which the sun seems to stand still.” In the next instant the bright yellow beach ball begins to descend, and we’re on our way to fall and winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Chris Christie Is Doing Something Very, Very Important
description: He’s telling the unvarnished truth. How gratifying is that?
content: Chris Christie made a complete fool of himself back in 2016, fan-dancing obsequiously around Donald Trump, angling for a crucial role in his administration, nattering on about their friendship, pretending or possibly even convincing himself that Trump could restrain his ego, check his nastiness, suspend his grift and, well, serve America. But then Christie, a former two-term governor of New Jersey, had plenty of company. And he never did style himself as some saint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: How E-Bike Battery Fires Became a Deadly Crisis in New York City
description: City leaders are racing to regulate battery-powered mobility devices, which have been the source of over 100 fires so far this year.
content: His girlfriend told him not to buy the electric scooter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Doc Antle of ‘Tiger King’ Is Convicted on Wildlife Trafficking Charges
description: Bhagavan Antle, who was found guilty on four felony counts, will be sentenced in September. He was cleared of the misdemeanor animal cruelty charges that he faced.
content: The owner of an animal park in South Carolina who was featured on the popular Netflix documentary “Tiger King” was convicted in Virginia last week on wildlife trafficking charges, state prosecutors announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli and Desiree Rios
title: A Subway Ride With Victor Wembanyama to Yankee Stadium
description: Wembanyama, the 19-year-old French basketball star, is in town for the N.B.A. draft. At more than seven feet tall, he’s hard to miss.
content: It was a rather unremarkable Tuesday at Central Park West and Columbus Circle. Vendors sold hot dogs, coffee and overpriced bottled water nearby. A light breeze rustled the sycamore branches hanging over a bicycle rental kiosk filled with neat rows of mint green helmets. Then, at 4:41 p.m., a black Mercedes van crept through the jam of buses, police vehicles and flower-adorned bicycle cabs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Wes Anderson’s Secret Weapon: The Camera Moves of Sanjay Sami
description: Sami brings ingenious design, a D.I.Y. spirit and pure athletic ability to the job of key grip — pushing and pulling heavy camera rigs with exacting precision.
content: Wes Anderson’s intricate films are known for their jewel box sets, vibrant costumes and starry ensemble casts. But there’s another element that gives his movies their distinctive look and feel, and it comes in the form of a 52-year-old grip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: A Britney Spears Jukebox Musical Hopes for #SeeBritney Energy
description: “Once Upon a One More Time” is bringing hits like “Toxic” and “Circus” to Broadway. Will Spears’s fiercely protective base embrace it?
content: The book writer for “Once Upon a One More Time,” the Britney Spears jukebox musical opening on Broadway Thursday night, often returns to a memory from five years ago, when Spears sat in a Manhattan theater a few rows in front of him and watched an early reading of the show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: How ‘Elemental’ Breathed Life Into Fire, Water, Earth and Air
description: The film’s director and production designer encountered challenges and took a few wrong turns as they worked on anthropomorphizing the natural world.
content: A woman made of fire falls for a man made of water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
title: Man Who Assaulted Officer on Jan. 6 Is Sentenced to More Than 12 Years
description: Daniel Rodriguez, whom the judge called a “one-man army of hate,” received one of the stiffest sentences so far in the Justice Department’s investigation of the Capitol riot.
content: A federal judge on Wednesday sentenced a rioter who savagely assaulted an officer defending the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, to more than 12 years in prison, calling him a “one-man army of hate” whose severe punishment might act as a deterrent to future acts of political violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Hundreds of Sea Lions Are Dying. Is an Algal Bloom to Blame?
description: Rescuers have been inundated with calls about sick and dying sea lions and dolphins along California’s central coast. They believe the cause is a toxin produced by a harmful algae.
content: The calls came in, one after the other, with reports of sea lions swaying their heads back and forth, foaming at the mouth, or slumped, lifeless on the beach. Rescuers along the central California coast struggled to keep up as they captured the sick animals in the hopes of saving them. Already, hundreds of sea lions and dozens of dolphins had died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Leily Nikounazar
title: In Iran, Some Are Chasing the Last Drops of Water
description: Lawmakers are warning that one province will run out within three months, and the shortage is inflaming tensions with the country’s neighbors.
content: Summer has come to Sistan and Baluchistan province, an impoverished fragment of chapped earth and shimmering heat in Iran’s southeast corner, and all people there can talk about is how to get water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: The Missing Titan Submersible, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Student Loan Pause Is Ending, With Consequences for Economy
description: Three years of relief from payments on $1.6 trillion in student debt allowed for other borrowing and spending — and will shift into reverse.
content: A bedrock component of pandemic-era relief for households is coming to an end: The debt-limit deal struck by the White House and congressional Republicans requires that the pause on student loan payments be lifted no later than Aug. 30.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof, Lucy King and Jonah M. Kessel
title: One Man’s Inspiring Journey to Lift His Country Out of Poverty
description: We’re told education can end poverty. The truth is more complicated.
content: Around the world we talk a good game about the importance of education, but we rarely act as if we mean it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beth Treffeisen and Glenn Thrush
title: Airman Pleads Not Guilty to Federal Charges in Leaks Case
description: The judge rejected a request to reconsider his earlier decision to hold Jack Teixeira without bail indefinitely.
content: Jack Teixeira, the 21-year-old Air National Guardsman accused of posting a trove of secret documents to an online chat group, pleaded not guilty to six counts of federal criminal charges on Wednesday, two months after his arrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Grace Ashford
title: N.Y. Lawmakers Confront Hot-Button Issues in Rare Return to Albany
description: The State Assembly reconvened to consider contentious bills on immigration, abortion, criminal justice and climate change.
content: Come late June, most state legislators in New York are typically far away from the Capitol in Albany, getting a jump on the summer after wrapping up their lawmaking duties for the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Shahzada and Suleman Dawood, Father-Son Passengers, Love Science Fiction and Travel
description: The expedition to the wreck of the Titanic followed a yearslong passion for science and discovery, according to friends and family.
content: Like the other passengers of the missing submersible, Shahzada Dawood loves adventure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Needelman
title: In Los Angeles, Bringing Food, Soap and the Salon to the Homeless
description: Through Beauty 2 the Streetz, Shirley Raines helps those without a home by administering a little “spiritual C.P.R.” Millions watch on TikTok.
content: More Than Likes is a series about social media personalities who are trying to do positive things for their communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Modi at the White House
description: Plus, missing submersible updates and the Kashmir migrants who died off Greece.
content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi arrived in Washington yesterday, beginning a state visit that the U.S. hopes will draw India closer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: The Best Summer Desserts Are the Classics
description: Store-bought ice cream is at the heart of these three easy desserts from Melissa Clark: a nostalgic banana split, a fruity take on a soda shop staple and the next best thing to a Chipwich.
content: Plopping pints of mint chocolate chip or cherry vanilla onto the table after a laid-back dinner is a time-honored summer tradition. Effortless and crowd-pleasing, store-bought ice cream is the beloved finale to countless hot-weather meals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: Three decades ago, a reporter took a plunge into wonder, and danger.
description: A dive in Alvin, a three-person submersible, revealed not only an alien world but why people engage in such risky pursuits.
content: We fell for an hour, the views out of our observation ports fading slowly to pitch darkness. That made it all the more interesting when, at the bottom of the Pacific Ocean in our three-person submersible, a mile and a half down, we lost power and the lights went out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: Rodeo is Turning America’s Whitest Big City Black
description: Like a rider wrestling a bull beneath bright lights, reconciling national narratives is not a pastime for the faint of heart.
content: A Black rodeo sounds like a good time at any time, but this is a particular moment in Portland’s near history. The city was a staging area for Black Lives Matter protests. That surprised a lot of people. For many years, Portland, Ore. held the distinction of being the whitest big city in the United States. From its inception, Oregon had laws that restricted the number of Black people within its borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bob Mehr
title: Dolby Atmos Wants You to Listen Up. (And Down. And Sideways.)
description: True believers in the immersive audio format say it could restore a musical appreciation lost to a generation that has come up during the streaming era.
content: After more than 30 years as a producer and engineer, Brad Wood wasn’t sure if he still had a future in music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Any Living Thing
description: Fill up on Jimmy Peniston’s Wednesday grid.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Julie Garwood, Best-Selling Romance Novelist, Dies at 78
description: She first became known for novels set in the distant past. She later wrote contemporary tales that involved computer hacking and Ponzi schemes.
content: Julie Garwood, a romance novelist whose books — some set centuries ago, some sampling present-day maladies like computer hacking and Ponzi schemes — routinely landed on best-seller lists, died on June 8 at her home in Leawood, Kan., on the Missouri border. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Hidden Horrors of Russian Treatment of P.O.W.s
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 21, 2023.
content: “It was a good day when you found a potato in your soup.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Intelligence Agencies May Never Find Covid’s Origins, Officials Say
description: The agencies are expected to release declassified material on what they have learned about Covid’s origins. People briefed on the material say there is no smoking gun.
content: For three years, the U.S. government has been tied in knots over the origins of the coronavirus pandemic, frustrated that China’s hindrance of investigations and unwillingness to look critically at its own research have obscured what intelligence agencies can learn about whether the virus escaped from a lab.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Child’s Friend Asked to Be Called a Name Used by Another Gender. Should I Do It?
description: A reader is unsure how to respond to a child’s wish to go by a different name after learning that the child’s mother decided not to honor the request.
content: Our 14-year-old child has a great circle of friends. I am often their chauffeur. The kids and I have friendly conversations in the car. Recently, one of them informed the group they would like to be called a different name — one that is typically associated with a different gender. The kids have obliged their friend, and I would be happy to, as well. But my wife told me that the child’s mother said she wasn’t going along with this request, though she didn’t say that other people shouldn’t. How should I proceed? I don’t want to alienate anyone or damage friendships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Calls Xi a ‘Dictator’ Who Was Kept in the Dark About Spy Balloon
description: At a campaign fund-raiser, the president said China’s leader was “very embarrassed” to not be informed about the surveillance craft that was shot down after crossing American airspace.
content: President Biden on Tuesday night called President Xi Jinping of China a “dictator” who had been kept in the dark by his own government about the spy balloon that crossed into United States airspace this winter before being shot down by an American fighter jet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: The Largest and Fastest Religious Shift in America Is Well Underway
description: We’re dechurching at a rapid clip.
content: This is the fourth newsletter in a series about Americans moving away from religion. Read part one, part two and part three.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: South Korea to Drop ‘Killer Questions’ From College Entrance Exam
description: The exam is notorious for extremely difficult problems, some of which seem to have little to do with the test topic. Even the president has complained.
content: Although the standardized test topic was the Korean language, the students had to answer questions about equity capital and risk-weighted bank assets. Problems on the “society” portion of the exam challenged them to decipher three-dimensional hypothetical analyses of Piaget’s theory of cognitive development.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Nightclub Druggings Left 4 Dead in 15 Days, Manhattan Prosecutors Say
description: Kenwood Allen’s victims were left unconscious on the street after he robbed them, authorities say. In all, he is accused of victimizing 21 people, killing five.
content: In just 15 days, Kenwood Allen killed four people, prosecutors with the Manhattan district attorney’s office said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: The war is worsening the effects of climate change, Kerry says.
description: The forced movement of people, the destruction of agricultural land and the increased instability are being felt in Ukraine and beyond, said John Kerry, President Biden’s climate envoy.
content: BRUSSELS — The war in Ukraine is aggravating the painful effects of climate change, causing not only severe damage in Ukraine, but also distress in a wider circle that includes Africa and South Asia, according to John F. Kerry, the United States special presidential envoy for climate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy Tarng
title: Dumped by Her Boyfriend, She Takes a Job Cuddling Others
description: The heroine of Jenny Xie’s debut novel, “Holding Pattern,” is back at her childhood home and learning to love herself.
content: As a plane awaits permission from air traffic control to land, it will trace a certain path in the sky — a period in suspension called a “holding pattern.” Jenny Xie’s debut novel, also called “Holding Pattern,” unfurls a similar period of in-between, with the protagonist Kathleen Cheng back in her childhood home in Oakland, Calif. Here she’s stagnant — fresh off a crushing breakup and preparing for her mother’s upcoming wedding, unsure if she wants to continue her graduate program back in Baltimore but not certain where else she’d want to land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum and Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: New Erectile Dysfunction Treatment Cleared for Over-the-Counter U.S. Sales
description: Eroxon, a topical gel, “helps men get an erection within 10 minutes,” according to Futura Medical, the manufacturer.
content: This month, the Food and Drug Administration approved the marketing of a new treatment for erectile dysfunction, a topical gel called Eroxon, meaning it can be sold over the counter in the United States. It is the first topical treatment for the condition to be made available without a prescription.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Two-Time Titan Diver Says Rescue May Depend on Passengers Staying Calm
description: Oisin Fanning, the passenger, said that Stockton Rush and Paul-Henri Nargeolet, who are on board the missing Titan, would have taken steps to conserve oxygen from the moment something went wrong.
content: Oisin Fanning, who made two deep-sea dives on the Titan last summer, said the passengers’ ability to survive on the missing submersible could depend on staying calm and avoiding panicked breathing that would use up more oxygen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariana Enríquez
title: What Horror Means to Me
description: Growing up in 1970s Argentina, fear was everywhere. It was also essential.
content: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: Who do you think you are? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Submersible Pilot’s Spouse Is Descended From a Famous Titanic Couple
description: Wendy Rush is a great-great-granddaughter of the retailing magnate Isidor Straus and his wife, Ida, two of the wealthiest people to die aboard the ocean liner.
content: Wendy Rush, the wife of Stockton Rush, the OceanGate chief executive who was piloting the submersible that disappeared Sunday during a dive to the Titanic wreckage, is a descendant of two first-class passengers who died when the ocean liner sank in 1912, archival records show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Eric Krupke, Will Reid, Luke Vander Ploeg, Shannon Lin, Rachelle Bonja, Paige Cowett, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: The Re-Militarization of Germany
description: The invasion of Ukraine is forcing Europe’s economic giant to dispense with taboos dating back to the postwar years.
content: In the decades after World War II and the atrocities of the Holocaust, Germany deliberately underinvested in its military. But that’s about to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb and Allison Zaucha
title: The Boot Camp for N.B.A. Hot Takes and Analysis
description: A two-day camp trains current and former basketball players in the lucrative art of broadcasting, podcasting and throwing verbal bombs on camera.
content: Alan Williams was the first person to brave the anchor desk, tucked away on a chilly set at the University of Southern California that was darkened, save for the spotlight on Williams in his black suit and blue-striped tie. Almost involuntarily, he lifted a hand from the desk’s shiny surface and nervously scratched his face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Bloch, Keith Collins, Marco Hernandez, Mark McKeague, Scott Reinhard and Helmuth Rosales
title: A Closer Look at the Submersible Lost in the North Atlantic
description: On the vessel, there were five passengers packed into a tight interior with no seats and a single view port 21 inches in diameter.
content: On the vessel, there were five passengers packed into a tight interior with no seats and a single view port 21 inches in diameter.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What’s In Our Queue? ‘The Thick of It’ and More
description: I’m a graphics and multimedia editor on The Times's Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

description: The inside story of a Times reporter’s strange role in a foundational moment in early internet culture: “The Dark Side of the Rainbow.”

title: Canadian Aircraft Searches for Missing Titanic Submersible
description: A Royal Canadian Air Force aircraft searched the surface of the Atlantic Ocean and used sub-surface acoustic detection capabilities to look for the missing submersible.

description: Fire and smoke billowed from an apartment building after an explosion in the French capital.

title: One Man’s Inspiring Journey to Lift His Country Out of Poverty
description: We’re told education can end poverty. The truth is more complicated.
